Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Female meiotic drive in Mimulus: a model for understanding the causes and consequences of selfish chromosomal evolution
Award.AbstractNarration:
Natural selection is expected to efficiently remove detrimental traits from animal and plant populations; yet, traits such as infertility persist in natural populations. Persistence of detrimental traits such as infertility may be caused by "selfish" behavior of chromosomes during meiosis, that is, chromosomes that carry harmful traits also carry genes for their own preferential inheritance. This research investigates the cellular and genetic mechanisms, evolutionary history, and fitness consequences of a selfish chromosome in the model wildflower Mimulus guttatus. The projects include cytogenetic determination of whether selfish chromosomal transmission (termed meiotic drive) is caused by divergence in chromosomal structure and/or function, crossing experiments to investigate the genetic basis of differences in the strength of meiotic drive, field measurements of the lifetime effects of carrying selfish chromosomes on reproduction, and surveys of the distribution of selfish chromosomes among populations.

Because research on Mimulus will allow tests of theories about the persistence of selfish chromosomes natural populations, these studies will provide rare insight into a poorly understood, but potentially ubiquitous (and highly influential), biological process. In addition, the project will develop, for broad dissemination, a set of laboratory modules using Mimulus as a model to teach fundamental concepts in genetics and evolution. Postdoctoral scholars, graduates, and undergraduate students will be engaged in generating these educational materials, as well as trained for careers in biology through participation in the research.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report - NSF 0846089

Not all evolution by natural selection increases population, or even individual, fitness. Specifically, selfish "drive" elements can spread through populations by maximizing their own genetic transmission, even if that comes at a cost to an organisms' fertility or survival. This project investigated the costs, distribution, and evolutionary dynamics of a driving chromosome in the common yellow monkeyflower, a model plant. Key findings included: 1) demonstration that female fitness costs (along with previously discovered male sterility) prevent the driving chromosome from taking over completely, but also make a large fraction of the population unexpectedly unfit 2) development of new population genetic theory for selfish elements, applicable to diverse systems 3) discovery that a key gene for cell division (CenH3, which is essential for all eukaryotic life and is also implicated in many cancers) is evolving under strong natural selection at multiple time-scales, and the generation of the first direct evidence that this rapid evolution is driven by interactions with selfish chromosome(s). These core findings were presented at multiple scientific meetings and disseminated as papers in three influential scientific journals so far. In sum, this research provides first empirical test (and confirmation) of core predictions of selfish centromere theory, which argues that conflict between chromosomes has shaped the basic biology of reproduction, can maintain damaging variants at paradoxically high frequency in plant and animal (including human) populations, and may drive the origin of species. The impact of these results goes far beyond monkeyflowers, as all higher organisms share the fundamentals of DNA replication and cell division, and are thus equally vulnerable to conflict among chromosomes.

In addition to achieving its focal research goals, this project has contributed substantially to the larger scientific endeavor. In particular, the genomic sequences and fitness data generated by this project have enhanced research focused on understanding the genes that cause speciation, the costs of selfish mitochondrial evolution, the effects of climate change on high-elevation plant populations, and the interactions between plants and soil fungi. These resources, archived with publication and (in the case of seeds) made available to the community by request, will continue to generate new insights into how plants evolve in response to both internal (genetic) and external (environment) factors. More broadly, this project directly contributed to the organization of a workshop focused on science education as part of the 2014 Mimulus Meeting (in Durham, NC), supporting the participation of six students and faculty at undergraduate-oriented institutions who would not have otherwise been able to attend. Educational modules using monkeyflowers to illustrate and explore core biological concepts were developed, implemented in classes at the University of Montana and the University of Georgia, and made available to the larger community. Numerous (>15) undergraduate students were individually trained in cutting-edge laboratory genetics and plant culture techniques, the scientific method, and communication skills, which enhanced their opportunities for both graduate education and employment in technological fields. The project contributed to the training of three graduate students and two postdoctoral researchers (all women); the latter have both secured faculty positions. Researchers supported by the project worked with K-12 students both in the classroom and in presentations at a local science museum.
